Introduction

A brain abscess is a localized infection within the brain parenchyma, characterized by a collection of pus surrounded by a capsule.  Brain abscesses are typically caused by bacterial infections, although fungal and parasitic infections are also possible.  Despite advancements in diagnostic imaging and treatment, they remain associated with significant morbidity and mortality, necessitating prompt diagnosis and intervention.

Pathophysiology



A brain abscess can be due to:



  • Hematogenous spread of bacteria from a distant location, most commonly the heart (eg, endocarditis) or lungs (eg, abscess, empyema).  This often leads to multiple abscesses, often in the territory of the middle cerebral artery near the gray-white matter junction; this likely occurs because vessels become more narrow at the junction, leading to a place for infectious emboli to get stuck.
  • Direct extension of a head and neck space infection, such as a dental infection, otitis media, sinusitis, or mastoiditis.  This usually results in the formation of a single brain abscess, often in the frontal (if due to sinus infection) and temporal lobes (if due to otitis media).


Pathogens vary by patient factors and infection origin.  Aerobic and anaerobic bacteria are common culprits.  The 2 most commonly isolated organisms are viridans streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus.  Fungal and parasitic infections may be seen in immunocompromised individuals, with organisms such as Aspergillus spp, Cryptococcus neoformans, Toxoplasma gondii, and Entamoeba histolytica.

Risk factors



Risk factors (

figure 1
) for the development of a brain abscess include:



  • Contiguous infections, such as sinusitis, otitis media, mastoiditis, and dental infections
  • Other distant infections (eg, endocarditis, chronic pulmonary infections)
  • Open head trauma or invasive neurosurgery
  • Immunocompromised status (eg, HIV/AIDS)
  • Cyanotic congenital heart disease.  The right-to-left shunting of venous blood through a ventricular septal defect allows bacteria to bypass the pulmonary circulation (where they are typically filtered and removed by phagocytosis) and spread to the brain.

Pathology



Histologically, brain abscesses exhibit central liquefactive necrosis surrounded by a layer of granulation tissue and a fibrous capsule.  Surrounding the abscess, reactive astrocytes and microglia proliferate, forming a glial scar.  On gross pathology, the abscess appears as a well-defined cavity filled with purulent material.

Clinical presentation



Symptoms of a brain abscess are often nonspecific and result from both local inflammation and increased intracranial pressure (ICP).  The classic triad includes:



  • Fever:  Fever is only present in about half of patients.
  • Headache:  Headache that is severe and nonresponsive to over-the-counter pain medications is the most common presenting symptom in patients with a brain abscess.  Headache may be positional and worse at night because ICP naturally increases in the supine position due to gravity.
  • Focal neurologic deficits:  Focal neurologic deficits are frequently present and depend on the location of the abscess.  Seizure may also be the initial manifestation in some patients.


Other signs of increased ICP, including mental status changes or nausea/vomiting may be present as well; although papilledema is a sign of elevated ICP, it takes days to develop and is seen in only a minority of patients with brain abscess.

Diagnosis



In patients with suspected brain abscess, the next step in diagnosis is contrast-enhanced neuroimaging; imaging typically reveals cerebritis initially, but within 1-2 weeks the infection consolidates to a ring-enhancing lesion (or multiple lesions) with central necrosis with surrounding edema (

image 1
).  CT scan of the brain is faster and more readily available; however, MRI is more sensitive for early cerebritis and does not use ionizing radiation.



Lumbar puncture is generally contraindicated due to the risk of herniation in the setting of increased ICP.  If this is performed, CSF may show elevated protein and white blood cells but is rarely diagnostic.  Blood cultures are positive in some cases of hematogenous spread and may be helpful for identifying causative organisms.  Confirmatory diagnosis requires CT-guided aspiration or surgical biopsy to obtain tissue for Gram stain and culture (bacterial, fungal, mycobacterial).

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis includes:



  • Herpes encephalitis:  usually causes acute symptoms including altered mental status, focal deficits, and/or focal seizures.  CT scan of the brain often reveals hypodense lesions in the temporal lobe.  Ring enhancement is uncommon.
  • A primary brain neoplasm (eg, lymphoma, glioblastoma) or metastasis:  can cause symptoms similar to a brain abscess with a single ring-enhancing lesion on imaging.  However, patients are less likely to have signs of infection (eg, fever, recent sinus or ear infection).
  • Bacterial meningitis:  can present with acute fever, headache, and vomiting.  However, meningeal signs (eg, nuchal rigidity) are often present on examination.
  • Ischemic stroke:  can present with focal neurologic deficits.  However, symptoms usually occur acutely compared to the presentation of brain abscess, and fever would not be expected.

Management



Most patients with brain abscess are treated with:



  • Empiric, intravenous antimicrobial therapy:  In general, antibiotics should cover both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria (eg, metronidazole, ceftriaxone, and vancomycin).  The empiric regimen may vary with the underlying condition; for example postoperative neurosurgical patients should receive vancomycin in combination with meropenem or cefepime (eg, for antipseudomonal coverage), and coverage for Toxoplasma and fungi should be considered in immunocompromised patients.
  • Needle aspiration or surgical excision of the lesion:  Needle aspiration is usually preferred because it is less invasive, but choice depends on the etiology and size of the abscess.


Corticosteroids may be considered for patients with significant mass effect or cerebral edema.  Antiseizure medications are used for patients with seizures, with continuation based on recurrence and risk factors.  After confirmation of the microbiology of the abscess, parenteral antibiotics are given for a prolonged period of time, usually 6 to 8 weeks, though this may be adjusted based on clinical and radiologic response.

Prognosis



Prognosis has improved with advances in imaging and surgical techniques but remains variable, with mortality rates of 10%-20% even with optimal treatment.  Factors associated with poorer prognosis include severe mental status changes on presentation and abscess rupture into the ventricles.  Seizures are the most common long-term sequelae from a brain abscess, although other long-term neurologic deficits are also possible.

Summary



Brain abscess (
